comments.commentBody: Please see my reply to RB from West Palm Beach. I would add that the notion of "impossible" has no place in a dialogue about democracy. In the recent Brexit referendum the "forward thinking" young stayed home, thus allowing the old, jaded ones, to hijack their futures, turning the "impossible" into the "unforeseen". I'm just sayin'...

Thank you for this reporting.  I am touched on so many levels and grateful for the human kindness and fortitude of both the sponsors and recipients, despite the challenges, teach us a lot.  Happy Canada Day to all Canadians and much thanks for your fine examples.

As a kid from Detroit, whenever we traveled across the Detroit River to Windsor, i would ask my Dad-"why can't we be like Canada?"

I still ask this question at 57.
Every person and every nation has times to be proud of and times to be ashamed of. The U.S. is a lost soul at the moment but will find its bearings eventually.

So what's your point? You lived in both the US and Canada, but you tell us nothing about those experiences, and then go off on an irrelevant tangent of difficulties in assimilating elsewhere, despite having no evidence of you having first hand knowledge of any kind. And it's not a question of assimilation, but rather integration.  Cheers!

Organized prayer times multiple times a day in mass groups are different from smoke breaks. Do you think working in a hospital I can just leave my patient to pray at certain time. It doesn't work that way in the west Lily! You all don't get it!
The refugees aren't guests. They are currently immigrants and are on their way to becoming proud Canadian citizens.

That's why CDN will always be "America, Jr." Pass the bills to someone else.

Again -- sponsored legal immigrants are one thing .. 13,000,000+ illegal immigrants (unsponsored) causing chaos is not helpful.

Wrong -- billions would flood into the USA, with a President Sanders. They think, if they get to the USA, they'll get free welfare, Social Security, and Medicare. It is a miracle, there are only 13,000,000+ illegal immigrants..

As a gay man who worries about my Muslim ex-boyfriend - and his immigrant family, who came to the United States with hardly anything, and are
now thriving - I'm afraid, too. I'm afraid of looming anti-LBGTQ violence, the hatred which you and I know better than most. I'm also afraid that Exceptionalism is corrupting decent Americans into believing lies about millions of refugees worldwide, who are fleeing unimaginable torture and destruction. I'm afraid of losing the true nature of the generous, welcoming American spirit - to a xenophobic meanness and embarrassing ignorance of world affairs. I'm afraid that partisanship will destroy any actual chance of our nation implementing a practical combination of rigorous background screening with the courage to deeply care about decent human beings from halfway around the world, suffering from policies in which the U.S. has had a formidable hand. And I'm afraid that Conservatives will read this piece, these comments - and either ignore their own withering human interconnectedness - or get even angrier and cold-hearted (read: full of fear of The Other, be it you and I as gay men, or desperate refugees of color) than they are now.

Orlando was a terrible tragedy but you still have a greater chance of being struck by lightning than being hurt by a terrorist. Don't give into fear - that's what the terrorists want you to do. Maintain a stiff upper lip and don't change a THING.
As a gay man, I think the massacre in Orlando highlights why people have a right to be afraid.

.
.
I don't suppose there was any sort of delay in your Comment showing up, Wags?

I avoided some of the words you used, because I SO non-ADEPT at getting my submissions past the emus.

Before the Arab Spring Syria was a very different place, and considered one of the most liberal (despite being ruled by a dictator) countries in the Middle East. Yes, there was racism and intolerance, but not on the scale you suggest. Freedom of religion has been guaranteed in the Syrian constitution for over 50 years, and homosexuality, while definitely not as accepted as it is in the west, was generally tolerated so long as you didn't get politically active about it. So no, there weren't pride parades, but many gay men were able to be out with their friends and families without fear of reprisal.
If suddenly the Syrian refugees somehow had full political control, as you fear, they would not take our country back to the dark ages...in fact you'd probably be safer here than in some of the southern States.
Canada is not  a socialist country and it is not true that the refugees haven't been properly screened.  The refugee process has the most intense security screening compared to other entry methods.
Socialism rules so much - I mean just look at what the government is doing to Venezuela! So smug.

Canada isn't Venezuela. Are you a product of the American education system? Canada's cities are all ranked much higher than US cities on quality of life. Between Canada and the US, it is the US which is more like Venezuela. I guess, according to your logic, that makes the US socialist? Please.

Oh poo poo!! This is a feel good article and not the real barometer of Canada. Not everyone here is welcoming the Syrian migrants. The government has pushed these migrants, yet, immigrants who have legitimately filled out the proper forms and have been waiting years to get into Canada have been pushed to the wayside. The Canadian government has pushed caution to the wind by not thoroughly investigating these people and that concerns  the general public. Canada is a socialist country where common sense has been tossed out the window, don't make the same mistake! Our prime minister was a drama teacher for godssakes!!

Just because, at the end of the day these people go home and maintain their way of life does not in anyway follow that it's "hostile and antagonistic" to anything. That's just your fear and arrogance (please note that these are indeed different from one another) talking. I can begin to understand European fears arising from proximity, complexity and shear volume of people. But the US has no such considerations (which goes for Canada as well) to deal with.

The elections based on likes and dislikes seem to be like high schools electing their prom queen. Elections of US Presidents make big economic and foreign policy changes and must be based on understanding of global issues.
The Presidential candidate must be a good negotiator and be calm in a crises. Obama is both since he has lived outside the US and seen the world from the point of view of an ordinary citizen.
I think Clinton has a hawkish streak but is good for the country. Iraq was a Bush legacy and may be her solution to use American might to solve problems is an old story. The world has changed and I am sure she sees that.
All this talk about un-trustworthiness is nonsense. Most women are very careful about expressing their opinions readily due to male hostilities towards capable and bright women. Besides the Republican strategy to use all kinds of tactics to stay in power seems to work on some voters who do not have time to research the issues and form an independent opinion of the candidates.

The refugees are screened by the UN when they first get to the camps, then they wait for years to be admitted to a country for resettlement. Yes, health needs are a factor, but when you've been living in the camp for years, (or outside working under the table, if you can find a job), you're at the top of the list for medical needs too.  ISIL hasn't sent agents to infiltrate the refugees that were settled under this new campaign, this group left Syria and came to the camps during the civil war before ISIL got involved. Yes, ISIL agents that came into the camps a year or two ago could still be there and on the list for resettlement, but they won't be resettled for at least another year or two...in other words it's safer to take them now, then later. Now, they could get radicalized while in the camp, but that just gives more impetus for the need to not only get them out and settled somewhere that they can actually have a chance at a better life, but to get the camps the aid they so desperately need, which lowers the chances of desperate people succumbing to their persuasions.

He said he would accept 10000 and so far we have received about five thousand, mostly families who have spent at least two years in a refugee camp. Stop spreading lies and watching Fox news. Fear is an ugly e
emotion
I guess you would prefer an incompetent narcissist to a highly qualified crook?

All these 'Schadenfreude' comments about Boris Johnson is really quite remarkable --
Especially when one takes into consideration that less than 24 hours ago, most of these same comments were cheering on the "people's revolution" brought about by the BREXIT vote in England....

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
The Brexit vote was on the subject of who controls immigration into Britain, Brussels or the English.
The E.U. insisted that they called the shots AND that no one who had made it to Greece, Italy, etc., could be stopped upon entering Britain and possibly sent back.
If THAT is not enough of an issue for you. you may accidentally be living in the wrong place.
He should ... He's the one who helped to sink it.

ABSOLUTELY NOT! Elections should not be reconfigured after they are held. Voters are responsible for their vote! Trump did not win the nomination by junta. If there is a problem, it is not with the process but with the American people. So, too, with England. All this talk about Brexit not necessarily meaning exit will only further damage democracy as a form of government.
God Bless the UK!
Well yes, but would you prefer that they had waited and surprised everyone with the bad news later?

Michael Gove has stated numerous times on television and radio that he does not have the stamina, leadership or intellectual temperament to be Prime Minister. And yet here we are!

Who needs House of Cards when the real thing is so much crazier
